Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Do Abstract Syntactic Representations Help Adult Second Language Learners Acquire Novel Word Types?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Some words do not directly translate into other languages. For example, where an English speaker would say either "John heard that Bill praised himself/him," depending on who is being praised, a Japanese speaker would say roughly "John-ga Bill-wa praised self heard-that," and mean either John or Bill was being praised. Him, himself, and the Japanese self are examples of anaphora, words that refer back to already-mentioned linguistic information (e.g. Bill or John). The use of anaphora is partly constrained by universal, syntactic principles, but also language-specific rules. This project investigates whether learners can develop native-like understanding of these cross-linguistically varied constructions from mere exposure, and if so what information is relevant and influential. This project, conducted in collaboration with Dr. Hajime Ono at Tsuda College, will form a cross-linguistic data-set that will allow the researchers to better understand the linguistic factors that enhance or reduce adults' ability to learn new words and grammatical constructions. Results from this project should provide insight into the kind of information that is especially relevant or influential in helping adults learn a new language.

This project seeks to better understand the nature of language learning mechanisms, and whether abstract syntactic representations can be used to acquire the correct interpretations of novel anaphora. Anaphora in both Japanese and English are constrained by universal principles, but language-specific parameters must also be learned. This project uses a novel language learning task developed by the awardee to test if the learning mechanism can track repeated co-occurrences of a word-form, syntactic representation, and context-based interpretations in order to map that word-form to the correct anaphora type, which will increase our understanding of the role of syntactic representations in the language acquisition process.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the nature and types of necessary and sufficient information sources that contribute to word learning is an important building block to understanding how adults learn second languages – and of course how children learn the meanings of words – but even how cultures innovate new meanings for old words or invent entirely new words.  Previous research investigating how learners acquire the meanings of words has shown that children and adults are good at tracking the distribution, across situations, of a word to an object or concept in the world, for example hearing “apple” whenever apples are relevant enables a mapping between the word and the concept. Research has also shown that children can learn about verb types just by tracking the distributions, across situations, of the types of sentences they are used in, for example learning that “hit” must involve a hitter and a hittee rather than just a hitter from hearing it used in sentences like “John hit Bill,” but never “John hit.”  These sentence structures themselves do not map linguistic elements to meaning based on some real-world context as described above; instead they map the structural location of a particular linguistic element in a mental representation of a sentence to some inferred yet variable meaning based on that structure and the context of use (see examples of “botu”, “sumu” and “togu” in the next paragraph.  This is an extremely complex task, yet we aimed to further the field’s understanding of the learning mechanism, and show that the learning mechanism can track this kind of distribution.

            Previously, we had presented English speaking participants with made-up words like “botu” and “sumu” that replaced words like “himself” and “him” (respectively) in English sentences like “John said that Bill splashed himself/him,” and asked them to try and learn the meaning or appropriate use of these words.  We also included another made-up word, “togu” modeled after a word that exists in Japanese, but not English.  This “togu” could be grammatically used to mean either the equivalent of English “himself” or “him” in the example sentence above, but not in a sentence like “The woman standing next to Bill splashed togu,” where “togu” could only be used to refer to the same person as “himself”.  In order to learn this, learners must track the location of the made-up words in the sentence in relation to the character name the word refers to (e.g. Bill in the previous example), because that location alone serves to differentiate the grammatical patterns of use for “botu”, “sumu”, and “togu”.  We manipulated the frequency of “botu”-like and “sumu”-like uses of “togu” across three different learning conditions and almost all participants subsequently accepted and produced “togu” according to the particular distribution they were shown, showing that they were in fact able to implicitly track that distributional information.  Unsurprisingly, these English speakers learned the grammatical pattern of use for “botu” and “sumu”, since they were modeled after words in their native language, but struggled to learn the appropriate use of “togu”, suggesting that distributional information alone is not sufficient to acquire these patterns of use if they do not exist in the learners’ native language.

Thanks to the EAPSI fellowship, we were able to collect data from native Japanese speakers in this same task, translated into Japanese.  Combining these data sets, we have found that Japanese speakers show almost the same pattern of results, strongly suggesting that one’s native language knowledge also does not provide influential evidence for acquisition words like “togu”.  Without data from native Japanese speakers, we would not have been able to conclude this.  Determining which aspects of language acquisition are subject to first language influence is a very active field of research, and has broader impacts for second language education.  For example, if first language knowledge aligns with a structure in the second language teachers can leverage that facilitative effect to help make these structures less opaque and difficult to learn.  Alternatively, influence could also hinder learning, and could provide information about which aspects of a language require more explanation or more practice.  Yet a third scenario, as may be the case with “togu”-like words, some structures may require extensive instruction despite some superficial similarity between the first and second language.  Educators should note this counter-intuitive finding.

            Returning to theoretical issues about the word learning mechanism more specifically, the intellectual merit of this project lies in our demonstration that although learners are capable of tracking distributions of syntactic structures themselves, this information alone is not sufficient to learn a word like “togu”.  One possible explanation for this, requiring further research, could depend on the kind of complexity involved in representing the partial overlap in use between “togu” and “botu” or “sumu” described above.
